entries.title: "i identify more with american culture
entries.text:
I identify more with American culture, but I think that is because I am a
foreigner living in China. If I was back home in Charlotte, NC, I may feel
excluded from the culture at times. Even watching from afar on social media, I
see how I identify less and less with my hometown and more with the people
around me (who also look more like me). I think being an adoptee has at times
definitely made it hard feeling close to Asian or Chinese-American culture
because I didn’t grow up in Asian environments. I didn’t have Asian family
members, so some of the commonalities many Asians have I feel left out of.
Still, I look Chinese and when a stranger sees me at first glance, they don’t
know my upbringing or background, so I am subject to discrimination just like
any other Asian looking person, so there is some solidarity in that. I may have
different life experiences than other Asians, but there is still a strong sense of
Chineseness or Asianness that can’t be stripped away even though I am
adopted.
What emotions/th

entries.title: My Finding Story
entries.text: I was told I was left and found outside of a police station.

entries.title: Family dynamics
entries.text:
As an adoptee, I’ve always had a broad definition of family as something that can cross
biological ties. I consider close friends and pets as family. At times, I feel a bit left out when
people talk about how they’re able to trace their genetic lineage more extensively since that’s
something I can’t really do. When I hear people talk about ancestors I think it’s something I’m
better able to relate to since, in my mind, the ancestors from my biological family sort of
conceptually transcend geographic barriers. The idea of ancestors makes me feel a bit more
connected to my biological family in a sense.

Overall, I don’t think being an adoptee has largely affected my relationships with my
close family members. My parents were always open to talking about adoption with both my
sister and I growing up. They made sure that we knew it was and still is okay to want to ask
questions and have a variety of emotions about being adopted. One family relationship that’s
been important for me as an adoptee is with my aunt. She’s from China and I learned a lot about
China through her. I’d say that relationship really helped me become more interested in my
Chinese heritage and the culture.

entries.title: Representation growing up
entries.text:
I lost my shit when Jeremy Lin got famous because for the first time I
felt like I had a role model. I was very annoying about it haha. I think besides
that we had mulan, but animated. I think now seeing more and more Asians
represented in media is great because I feel like our collective identities are being
recognized, but also every story is unique and our differences are celebrated. I
also feel extremely privileged to have only worked for Asian women since I
graduated from NYU Shanghai. It is so inspiring to have someone who looks like
you as a role model every day and to feel confident that you can be in their shoes
one day. Of course this is because these individuals are actually great leaders and
not just Asian women, but it does help that I feel a connection to them. I worry
that if I return to the US, I wouldn’t feel as empowered in my workplace.

Hmmm I am so lazy all things hair/fashion/makeup haha. My mom didn’t let me
use eyeliner or mascara growing up because my eyes are different and my
eyelashes kinda fold in. This didn’t upset me or anything, but it feels kinda silly
like my white mom trying to protect her special Chinese baby haha. She also
never made me eat cereal because she worried I was lactose intolerant. Anyways,
I’m not big into makeup but that’s really just my personal choice. I don’t feel like
I adopt Asian trends, but I do love Uniqlo! Not sure if that counts really and I
think it’s less related to being adopted and more related to personal preference
and the cost haha.

entries.title: Interracial Family
entries.text:
One specific thing I wish my family knew or understood better about being an adoptee,
especially in an interracial family, is how my race impacts me on a day to day basis. It’s hard to
explain to them how big of a factor that is for me since they don’t necessarily look at me as being
too racially different as their child.

entries.title: What are you?
entries.text:
When people ask where I’m from I tell them the town where I grew up in the U.S. and
leave it at that unless they ask more questions. If they ask about my ethnicity, I’ll say I’m
Chinese. The general label I like to use is Chinese American.

entries.title: I identify with Asian-American culture
entries.text:
I would say I most strongly identify with Asian American culture and bits of Chinese
culture. Generally, I feel like Asian American culture is most relatable or identifiable for me
because there’s so many other Asian Americans and adoptees have shared experiences within the
culture. In my experience, I think being an adoptee adds more complexity when it comes to
certain cultural identifications, though I don’t think it makes it too difficult to identify within a
culture. I think when you’re growing up as an adoptee there isn’t always a big focus on the fact
that you’re adopted so you’re able to take part in certain cultures more freely.

I get irritated and frustrated when I hear adoptees being referred to as such because it
implies that we had a choice in how we were raised and in which communities we were raised in.
It also just illustrates the expectations others impose on us just for being Chinese. For me, I think
people calling adoptees or other Asian Americans in general “white-washed” or “too Chinese” or
“not Chinese enough” also shows how the idea of being Chinese differs for so many people. I’ve
been called white-washed plenty of times and my response is usually along the lines of “Well,
yeah. My whole family is white, it’s kind of unavoidable.”

entries.title: Growing up was like this
entries.text:
Growing up, did you feel like there were enough people in your school, community, on TV, on
social media, etc. that looked like you or had a similar experience as you, and in what ways did
this affect you, then and now?
Growing up, I felt like there were a decent amount of people who looked like me at my
school all the way into high school, which helped me feel less like an outsider compared to how I
felt with my extended family. Due to that, I think I was more open to learning more about Asian
(Chinese) culture. As far as seeing people that looked like me or had similar experiences as me in
the media while growing up, it was something I didn’t realize was lacking until movies and
shows with Asians as central characters started coming out more recently. The first time I really
noticed this was after I watched the movie To All the Boys I Loved Before, which has a female
Asian American lead. On top of that, the actress who plays that role was also adopted! This
definitely highlighted the lack of representation in film, TV, social media, etc. I experienced
growing up. Now there’s been a significant increase of people who look like me in the media as a
whole, which truly just makes me feel seen and more validated in terms of identity.

entries.title: How I was found
entries.text:
From what I can recall, I was left on
the doorstep of the orphanage on September 15, 2002 and I was identified as around 3
days old.

entries.title: Missing heritage
entries.text:
I would definitely define ‘family’ as those that you love
unconditionally as return that same affection. Whenever people have spoken
about their ancestry in the past, it kind of felt like I had a missing heritage
because I knew that there is existing information that I had no way of accessing.
Asking my mom about her own ancestry was cool, but it never directly
translated to me so it did not feel very fulfilling in a sense. As a child, I always
wanted to know more about my biological family similarly to how people know
their family tree. I had a project in elementary school where we made family trees
and it felt so impersonal when asking my parents because it wasn’t truly mine.

entries.title: They insist I'm beautiful
entries.text:
This is kind of a
hard question because my parents hold Chinese culture in high regard and have
had some efforts to help my sister and I stay in touch with our culture as kids. I
guess maybe the racial aspect I wish they understood more, especially during my
angsty, omg I hate everything, prepubescent, middle school years. For me
personally, I was always super aware of how I was perceived because I stood out
a lot in my circle of friends because they were all white. My parents never
understood why I thought that boys wouldn’t find me attractive because I was
Chinese because, as most parents believe, they insist that I’m beautiful.

entries.title: To be honest, I kind of avoid saying I'm adopted
entries.text:
To be honest, I kind of avoid
saying that I’m adopted. I know that it’s an interesting part about myself, but I
don’t like to stand out that much and I don’t see it as much of a big deal. I often
forget that whenever I make friends I don’t tell them I’m adopted and they’re
surprised when I show them my family and they’re all white. There have been
times when months after befriending someone they go “Wait you’re adopted?”
because a lot of the time I just assume that everyone knows. So for “What are
you?” I usually say Chinese and “Where are you from?” I say South Carolina. But
in China I usually just say ABC. Culture means to me both the environmental and
ethnic part of one’s identity. I think this definition mostly applies for people that
are still “near” their family’s country of origin and the country they grew up in. I
mean near in a timely sense. Because I wouldn’t say that someone’s family that
immigrated to America from Germany in the 1400s is also culturally German. For
adoptees this definition would make sense because many of us grew up in
American culture but want to understand their “birth culture.” So culture to me is
different from my hometown community because their culture is just American
but because of the adoptee's complicated beginnings, culture means much more.

entries.title: Being American
entries.text:
I would say that I am extremely American.
I identify with this culture because it’s what I grew up in. No matter how long
I live in China or learn about Chinese culture, I will never be able to be fully
integrated into it because I am missing the mindset and nuances that come
along with growing up Chinese. As I said above, I can say that Chinese culture
is “mine” but not in the way that I understand what it’s like to be a part of it, I
can only understand it as a foreigner. Being adopted doesn’t impact me as
much because I am extremely ignorant in Chinese culture. I compare myself a
lot to ABCs these days. This is because I technically am more Chinese than
them, but they are more culturally Chinese in every sense because of their
exposure from their family.

entries.title: College in China
entries.text:
I think of embarrassment whenever hearing these
words because “white-washed” has definitely been used to describe me. Now
that I’m in college in China this affects me more because when you’re surrounded
by white people all the time, no one notices cultural things because you’re
American. But in China, being surrounded by ABCs, I feel ashamed whenever I’ll
be around them speaking Chinese with each other because I feel like I should’ve
been learning Chinese all this time so I can communicate and understand what’s
going on. Going about daily life in China makes me ashamed too because I know
that the people around me are judging me because I look Chinese and have no
idea what they are saying to me. I kind of have a theory that I’m like the lowest
of the low on the foreigner tier list because white people are tolerated and even
admired, but an Asian person that only speaks English just seems disrespectful.

entries.title:
I was performing for this culture by the
way I dress and put on makeup
entries.text:
here was like zero representation throughout my childhood.
However, I actually have 2 adopted cousins but they live across the country
and they never really felt the need to connect to China like my sister and I did
so there was kind of a disconnect there. But the overall lack of not seeing East
Asian people made me wish to be white as a kid because most of the people
close to me were white and attractive and popular. So I convinced myself that
if only I was white I would be more popular and attractive. People definitely
weren’t mean to me but I could tell I wasn’t really considered attractive and it
was hard for me to distinguish if it was because I was an awkward teen or
Asian, maybe it was a bit of both. I think I kind of put my pretty, white
friends on a pedestal. Whenever I secretly got into K-Pop a few years ago I
realized that East Asia wasn’t a place that adored white people and all their
media wasn’t eurocentric. The popularity of Asian media that began to rise
made me realize that the world doesn’t revolve around America which
shocked me because there’s that saying that many people believe that’s like
“We’re so lucky to be born here and live here because of all the freedom we
get.” These days, I feel like I am trying to cater to Asian beauty standards more
than Western. I feel like in America, I was performing for this culture by the
way I dress and put on makeup, and I felt like I mastered it in a way. But now
that I’m in China it’s kinda putting me in an identity crisis because the
standards here are so different and I’m often frustrated that I haven’t been able
to change to the Chinese aesthetic. It does take a toll on my self esteem here
because I feel like the most ignorant American ever and I keep thinking about
what it would’ve been like to grow up in China and not feel so out of place.

entries.title: Where I am from: Maoming, Guangzhou
entries.text:
I was found near the entrance of an office building in downtown Maoming, Guangzhou.
It was somewhere with a lot of foot traffic, so someone had found me easily.

entries.title: How i see family
entries.text:
As an adoptee I see family as something that is beyond just blood relation. Sometimes
people would ask whether I was “real” family with my parents and my sister and I would
always respond that of course I am. I see it as a deep bond, connection, and love rather
than just something having to do with bloodline or direct lineage.

entries.title: Looking different
entries.text:
There have been times where I have been mistaken for my sibling’s friend since we do
look a bit different. There have also been times where people do not think I am my
parents’ child when we have been out running errands or something like that.
10. I think it was in elementary school when I started to realize that my appearance was
different from those around me. I felt isolated a bit since I was different and even more
so when others would notice too. There was a Western beauty standard that I felt I did
not fit and that made it difficult to accept and appreciate my own beauty.

entries.title:
Re: I was performing for this culture by the
way I dress and put on makeup
entries.text:
I think I tend to adopt more hair and fashion trends from Western sources since there is
so much from the media that I am influenced by, but I have been adopting more
makeup trends from Asian sources. Western sources for makeup is also kind of limited
from some of the representation of different physical features of the face and
particularly my eye shape.

entries.title: Biological family
entries.text:
I am lucky enough to find that my adoptive family aligns with the typical
understanding of what a biological family would be and feel like, I just look
different. Saying “adoptive family” doesn’t feel genuine. They are just my family
even with all of our differences and disagreements. Still, I can feel a bit ostracized
by my extended family that are white and generally not as progressive as my
direct family members. For much of my childhood, I would sort of insert myself
into my parents’ family lineage. I genuinely found their European ancestral
stories and lineages to be intriguing even though I didn’t actually have a
connection to it myself. For an elementary school project on tracking family
heritage, I told the story about my family’s Italian and Jewish background and
not my own story coming from China.

entries.title: My interracial family
entries.text:
The largest area where my relationship with my family is complicated is in
the fact that I am a POC and they are white. There are simply some things
about being Asian that they will never understand. My relationship with
them is complicated by this obvious difference that I never truly learned how
to communicate. In the past, I didn’t feel comfortable communicating that I
want them to be more understanding of their whiteness and do more for
movements like Black Lives Matter. I have felt guilty for this. I also view
adoption much differently than I did before. It is such a nuanced experience
that I view somewhat negatively, but I have not shared this feeling with my
family.

Their whiteness! The controversies of transnational and transracial
adoption are probably lost to them. I have heard other people talk about
being adopted as having to “grieve a lost family.” This is such a poignant
sentiment, but I think it does speak to my experience. It’s so hard to
rationalize this part of myself with my largely positive and supportive
upbringing.
Their whiteness! The controversies of transnational and transracial
adoption are probably lost to them. I have heard other people talk about
being adopted as having to “grieve a lost family.” This is such a poignant
sentiment, but I think it does speak to my experience. It’s so hard to
rationalize this part of myself with my largely positive and supportive
upbringing.

entries.title: Being ABC
entries.text:
For the first time, someone asked me if I was an ABC. For simplicity, I just said
yes. These questions of where are you from can feel very different depending on
who is asking. Usually, I say I am just from California and that I am Chinese. It
took me a long time to even say I am Chinese! I can say I am Chinese, but I know
this label means something very different to many of the Chinese Americans that I
grew up with. To me culture refers to shared customs, ideologies, and experiences
in a group. My understanding of culture is shaped by being Asian American,
queer, and a Chinese adoptee that grew up in the white suburbs. I feel very partial
in these communities. My experience is unlike most others. I didn’t grow up in a
Chinese household, but I am also not a white person. As I have left my
hometown, I have done a lot for myself to experience Chineseness apart from my
white hometown and family. It is very rare to find other people that share these
intersectional identities. Finding people that share even a part of these experiences
is incredibly meaningful.

entries.title: Looking different
entries.text:
For me, I think this has significantly impacted me. I remember quite young just
thinking that NOBODY looked like me. There were plenty of East Asian Chinese
people, but they were either paler, taller, thinner, girly, or boyish. I was none of those.
Of course, this not fitting in was also deeply connected to my queerness and presenting
androgynously, but I have a feeling that not seeing anyone that looked like me in my
school, community, or media impacted me greatly. I think recently I’ve begun to process
this. I still don’t really see that many people that look like me. This lack of
representation makes it hard for me to see what my future looks like and IF I have a
future. Additionally, I remember not really comprehending what being asian meant until
I experienced some microaggressions and racism in middle school. Suddenly, all of my
peers had figured out that they could weaponize their whiteness against me when I did
better on a test or to laugh at me when I was placed in the lower leveled math class.
This wasn’t something that my white family prepared me for!

entries.title: Growing up with other adoptees
entries.text:
Strangely, I grew up around a handful of other Chinese adopted girls. A few
of us are still very close friends. Still, I look quite different than my Chinese
peers. A lack of Asian-queer representation in the white suburbs really gave
me a mindset that whiteness was default. Now, I try to surround myself with
more poc and queer people. Mainstream asian representation is still so weak
and what is there, doesn’t really represent me either. There was a period where
I learned that a lot of the hair styles of white people just didn’t work for my
thinner Asian hair. My navigation from “white” styles to styles created by and
for Asian people was something I’ve had to do on my own.

entries.title: Finding story
entries.text:
I was told that I was left on a doorstep of some sort, wrapped in a blanket inside a basket. On top of me I
had a note with my assumed birthday, which is the one I celebrate today.

entries.title: I define family as...
entries.text:
I define family as my parents who raised me and both sides of my parents as my family. To me, I also
include the family friends who helped raise me and were closely involved in my childhood. When people
mention “lineage” or “ancestry” I do refer to my unknown Chinese relatives, and the first thought that
comes to mind is that I don’t know mine. One thing that has always bothered me is that I don’t know my
genetic heritage and never know what illnesses I could be predisposed to. It occured to me very early on
as a child when I was asked at the doctor if my family has “history of heart disease” or “history of mental
illness”
.

entries.title: Family relationships
entries.text:
Familial Relationships:
Being adopted never really affected my family relationships, with my parents at least. It didn’t change
anything for me, and I always knew I was adopted and that my parents loved me just as if they were my
biological parents. For extended family, I didn’t feel like I was seen differently in the family however I
did have different bonds with cousins and family my age. I didn’t feel fully included as a cousin, missed
family trips, and wasn’t invited to cousin bonding that my cousins all did without me.
Familial Understanding:
There's nothing my parents pushed under the rug, or sugar coated when talking about my adoption. I think
I wish they understood the struggle of being an Asian American that is adopted, with the struggles I faced
in school. However there's nothing else I wish they payed more attention to or understood.

entries.title: What are you
entries.text:
I was always stunned by the “What are you” question, so I’d beat around the bush to make the other
person feel bad. I’d rather them ask my ethnicity, to which I’d answer Chinese. When they asked where
specifically, I had no shame or embarrassment in saying I was adopted from JiangXi province.
Culture:
Culture to me means my Chinese heritage, and whatever knowledge I had of it at the time. As I grew and
had more Chinese friends I began to understand and celebrate more. My understanding was smaller than
others in my community but I tried my best growing up and still educating myself to fully embrace my
own culture.

entries.title: Being called whitewashed
entries.text:
Anger, frustration and sadness. I have been called those names numerous times and it's really mostly
frustration because of my situation. Others don’t understand that identity can encompass many different
things and there’s different aspects to an individual's identity.

entries.title: Asian-american presence in my life
entries.text:
I always knew I had a different appearance the minute I went to grade school. I vaguely remember
realizing my eyes were smaller, my hair was a lot darker and lacked texture and that I had a completely
different face shape. I didn’t struggle with my appearance or different appearance until I was in middle
school though, when girls got a lot more obsessed with western beauty standards and started comparing
themselves to each other.
Community Appearance:
No, not many people had a similar appearance to me growing up. I really lacked Asian American
presence in my life growing up during my developmental years but in high school the community became
more apparent to me. I did have a couple adopted Chinese friends growing up so that really helped me
realize that I wasn’t going through certain realizations alone though. I think this mostly affected who I felt
confiding in, as I really only confided in my Chinese American friends about certain things pertaining to
my identity and feelings about it.

entries.title: How I was found was lucky
entries.text:
I was told that I was found on a street by a couple policemen who had said that I
was born only 1-3 days before being left. It was reported that I still had my
umbilical cord but was bundled in layers and layers of clothes to keep me warm
with a rope that tied all the clothes and blankets together. I was in a basket on
the side of a sidewalk close to a police station. I was told that my parents loved
me so much that they wanted me to be found. This made me “lucky” because
many unwanted children were left to die in fields, which is honestly a horrifying
story to tell a young child

entries.title: Re: I define family as...
entries.text:
My definition of family is primarily my adopted mom and dad, though I rarely
think of them as my “adopted” family unless it’s in contexts that revolve around
adoption. They are my family because they provide me with love, guidance, and
emotional support.
Personally, I feel quite removed when people talk about their “lineage.” To me, this
topic has never been accessible because I was never provided with information or
access to information about my genetics, ancestors, or lineage. I think it’s amazing
when people are able to talk about this and it makes me a bit envious because I
wish I knew more about my background, but at the same time I don’t really think
about this nearly as often as I did when I was younger.

entries.title: Having little knowledge to describe what i felt
entries.text:
To my mom and dad, I am viewed as their child, without any additional
qualifiers, but to my extended family and I suppose society at large, I am
viewed as their adopted child, which at times can make me feel dysphoric in
my identity. I used to feel really uncomfortable with this because while I
viewed myself as their child and them as my parents, I would always get asked
why they don’t look like me, why they are so much older than me, or if they
were my neighbors. As a child, I never asked for this type of scrutiny and it
made me withdraw heavily into myself when I was around classmates and my
parents. I felt embarrassed, burdened, and uncomfortable to have to be
reminded of being abandoned with little vocabulary or knowledge to navigate
or combat these feelings, so I think eventually I started to not have my friends
be around them and never brought people to my house; I would always go to
theirs. I think this type of defensiveness instilled at a young age made me
become instinctively protective of my parents when people talk about them
because I would constantly have to defend my reason for being here, existence,
and identity. This was one of many challenges that I’ve faced, but it’s an
unfortunate one because I felt as though my home was my safe space and I
didn’t let anyone in.
Another challenge that I’ve faced concerns how I process race-related
suffering. As I am becoming more and more aware of racial inequalities and
inequities, along with systems of oppression, I have been faced with a certain
level of cognitive dissonance. When I see or talk about traumatic events that
are happening to the Asian-American community, I feel a level of fear, anger,
and sadness but because of my identity, I often feel like I have not suffered
enough to be allowed to feel these emotions, so I’m left feeling helpless to my
own emotions. While I look like those who were and are being targeted, I have
features in my personality, the way I speak, and privilege of a white person
that I’m only beginning to unpack.

entries.title: I wish there had been more shows ...
entries.text:
Growing up, I honestly did not notice because I was so immersed in Western
culture that I would forget that I'm not white, which is very strange to say, but
it's true. Thinking back now, I wish there had been more shows that would touch
on the effects of adoption and make that experience more documented so
children could understand how to identify with their culture without living with
people who are Chinese.

entries.title: Accurate family
entries.text: Family means many different things to me. I define it as the people who surround you that love and support you no matter if you’re blood related or not. I have been in many situations when the terms “lineage” or “ancestry”/”genetics” are brought up. Usually these terms are brought up in science classes. I remember being in sophomore biology class, we were studying genetics and the assignment was “create your own punnett square based on your own genetics from your parents.” Obviously I couldn’t create an “accurate” square since I’m not biologically related to my parents. I never ended up saying anything since I felt weird bringing it up to my teacher but, deep down it did make me feel uncomfortable since it seemed I was the only one in this situation

entries.title: It feels weird to say Chinese-American
entries.text: This is one of the hardest topics and challenges about being an adoptee especially from Asian countries. When people ask me “what are you” it feels weird to say Chinese-American since I’m technically 100% chinese...yet I grew up in the US. Part of me feels like I should be more connected with my Chinese side but nothing about my family is Chinese. It’s hard because I see myself as white or your typical American yet I’m Asian.

entries.title: People say to me "I'm sorry"
entries.text: Recently my dad remarried and his new spouse is Asian, like me. There’s never been a time where people mistaken her as my mom but whenever we’re out in public I always think that’s what people are thinking. When I meet people for the first time, they automatically assume that I’m mixed which doesn’t really bother me. When people find out that I’m not only adopted but adopted by white people, their reaction changes. I have had people say to me “I’m sorry” that is what bothers me. Not everyone who is adopted has a depressing story and sometimes I feel like people just assume things that aren’t true.

entries.title: Growing up in an inclusive environment
entries.text: I was lucky enough to grow up in an inclusive environment so I actually never thought about how I looked different until I was in high school. High school was when I started noticing how I was different. Starting in senior year, I started to realize that I mainly had been surrounding myself with white kids and my mannerisms matched theirs. I thankfully never had anyone be directly racist towards me but when COVID-19 started, so did the Asian hate. It bothered me a lot even though it didn’t directly affect me. This is when I started to really realize how “white-washed” I really was. Surrounding myself with white kids isn’t necessarily bad but it did open my eyes to the concept of people surrounding themselves with the kinds of people that they were raised with.

entries.title: My Finding Story
entries.text:
I was found at a bus stop in a box with baby formula and a spare set
of baby clothes. A cleaning lady took me to the police station which
sent me to an adoption site.

entries.title:
I can’t think of anything I
wish my family understood better
entries.text:
Being an adoptee doesn’t really affect my relationship with my
family, because I was adopted at a very young age, so I don’t really
have anything to compare its difficulty with. My family does a great job at being transparent with me about my
adoption experience. With that being said, I can’t think of anything I
wish my family understood better besides the language (Chinese).

entries.title: How I truly identify
entries.text:
As a college student, being asked where you are from typically refers to
your hometown not where you were born, so I typically respond with
“Tualatin” or “Portland”. Labels I use include Chinese, Asian etc. I’m
currently taking an anthropology class, so I feel like my understanding of
culture may come from a more academic standpoint in that I’m able to
view culture as an intersectionality of multiple different aspects of life. I
believe adoptees identifying with multiple cultures are able to better
perceive the world around them instead of taking a linear viewpoint.

entries.title: How I truly identify
entries.text:
As a college student, being asked where you are from typically refers to
your hometown not where you were born, so I typically respond with
“Tualatin” or “Portland”. Labels I use include Chinese, Asian etc. I’m
currently taking an anthropology class, so I feel like my understanding of
culture may come from a more academic standpoint in that I’m able to
view culture as an intersectionality of multiple different aspects of life. I
believe adoptees identifying with multiple cultures are able to better
perceive the world around them instead of taking a linear viewpoint. It can be difficult at times to determine which cultures I truly identify with,
but I would say I identify with both American and Chinese culture.

entries.title: The only POC at school
entries.text:
I don’t recall an exact time I remember noticing the difference, but it most
definitely was accentuated in middle school. Going to an all-Chinese
immersion elementary school made being an adoptee more normal, but
going to a public middle school with an extreme lack of diversity was a
wake up call. I didn’t really like being one of the only POC at school until
high school where I became comfortable in my own skin and it stopped
bothering me. the stereotypes were harsh and my school lacked a lot of diversity. As
I said before, in middle school I tried to assimilate and fit in the best I
could, but I stopped in high school. However, I still don’t tell anyone I’m
adopted unless it comes up in conversation or we’re close friends.

entries.title:
Re: Re: I was performing for this culture by the
way I dress and put on makeup
entries.text:
I probably adopt most trends from Western sources, because social media
platforms typically idealize and accentuate American culture. Being an
adoptee doesn’t play into the process for me.

entries.title: This depends on where i am
entries.text:
This definitely depends on where I am. Since I’m in China, I say I am American
and if a Chinese person asks more I say I’m a 美籍华人 / Chinese-American. To
other foreigners I also say I am American and may mention I was born in China,
but adopted at age one.

entries.title: Re: This depends on where i am
entries.text:
In the US, I say I’m Asian/Chinese from Atlanta, Georgia. In China, I
say I’m American 美国人 from Atlanta, Georgia. I prefer to say
Asian/Chinese-American initially. To me culture is a mix of where you
are raised and what you identify as. I don’t say I’m only Asian or only
American because that ignores the other parts of my identity.

entries.title: Re: This depends on where i am
entries.text:
In the US, I say I’m Asian/Chinese from Atlanta, Georgia. In China, I
say I’m American 美国人 from Atlanta, Georgia. I prefer to say
Asian/Chinese-American initially. To me culture is a mix of where you
are raised and what you identify as. I don’t say I’m only Asian or only
American because that ignores the other parts of my identity.

entries.title: what it says in my legal documents
entries.text:
I was told that I was found outside of the orphanage gates. I don’t know anything else. I also
haven’t seen it written in any of my legal documents, so I’m not sure how my adoptive
mother came to learn this information. I’m also not sure if she made it up in order to have
more of a ‘story’ when I asked her about my origins.

entries.title: I wish I knew
entries.text:
I have a complicated relationship with my adoptive family. To me, I believe that true family
is the people that you choose to keep around you. The people whom you love and who love
you. You might not always like each other, but the love runs deep. I have found family in
close friends and that’s enough for me. Truthfully, words like “lineage” and “ancestors”
don’t bother me. However, I do wish that I knew more about my genetics. Thinking
practically, it would be so helpful to know if any diseases run in the family or what I am
likely to inherit later on. But I also would love to know if I look like either of my parents, if I
have any siblings out there who resemble me. Looking back, I was always secretly jealous
when friends of mine would come from families who all had similar features because I
never had that.

entries.title: It was never a conversation in my house
entries.text:
My sister was also adopted from China, a few years after I was. Fortunately, I didn’t feel
different from her in the sense that she was biological and I was not. Three of my cousins
were also adopted, one from the Philippines and two were domestic US adoptions.
Adoption was actually quite normalized in my family because of that. My mom was always
very intentional in being open with our adoption stories and would tell them over and over
again whenever we asked to hear them. Ever since I can remember, she would read this
children’s book called “I Love You Like Crazy Cakes” about a woman who travels to China
to adopt her daughter. I personally think that book was a very good decision and I
appreciate having heard it over and over again. Despite all of us being adopted, my cousins
and sister and I never talked about it. It was never really a conversation in our house.
Maybe it felt like we’d talked it to death as young children and we were content with
pretending it didn’t exist anymore. It’s not as if I felt like I needed or wanted to talk about it,
either. I was more than happy trying to blend in as a ‘normal’ person. I think it’s interesting
talking to other adoptees and asking how much their adoption was talked about over the
years within their families. I honestly don’t think my family did anything particularly wrong. They didn’t push either
identity on me. I remember one year, my mom printed off coloring sheets and ordered
Chinese food for my kindergarten class on Chinese New Year Day. At the time, I didn’t really
understand the significance and I was just happy about being the most popular kid in class
that day. But looking back now, I see the intention and the heart behind it, but I also see the
wrongness of it. She wanted to do something to celebrate one part of my identity, but it felt
like a showy and inauthentic way to do so.

entries.title: Re: What are you?
entries.text:
I almost always respond to people that I’m from the US. Because it’s true. That’s the identity
that I feel closest to and the one that I’ve known the longest. It doesn’t bother me as much
as it used to, maybe because I’ve come to expect the question from people. If pushed, then,
yes, I’m Chinese-American. But I tend to only identify myself as American because it feels
right. I’m Chinese, but I don’t own that identity. It gets awkward when people tell me that I
don’t look Chinese. I never know how to respond to that. I’ve had so many people tell me I
look like a different ethnicity, to which I usually awkwardly laugh and say I don’t know my
genetics so it’s possible. Part of me is curious at the fact that so many people think I don’t
look Chinese. But also a part of me wants to tell them that it’s none of their business.

entries.title: Accessing Chinese identity
entries.text:
I hear the word ‘culture’ and I think of a more sociological definition. To me, at it’s most
basic understanding, it’s the learned language, customs, and beliefs shared within a people
group. My learned language was English. My learned customs were of Western origins. My
learned beliefs were based on Roman Catholic ideology and Western principles. My own
understanding of culture was shared by the people from my community growing up. That is
very different from my current community here in Shanghai. People have a broader
understanding of culture as people are from/exposed to a variety of cultures. For example,
one of my closest friends here is from the United States as well. But she immigrated to the
US from the Ukraine as a young child and she still feels a strong connection to her
Ukrainian cultural identity. I think the fact that her parents are both strongly tied to their
Ukrainian origins plays a role in that, but it has been interesting conversing with others
who have somewhat dual cultural identities and hearing how they understand themselves.
I know it doesn’t have to be one or the other – American or Chinese. But I think that,
growing up, it very much felt that way. To the point where I ignored and tried to erase my
Chinese identity in an effort to be as American as I could be. And I don’t know if I have (or
want) access to that Chinese identity anymore.

entries.title: I was once called a common white girl, and I was proud of it.
entries.text:
I was called a common white girl once. And I was proud of it. I think for so much of my life
and even now, if I’m being honest, I’ve simply wanted to fit in with the other girls. Who
were predominantly white in the social circles and school district that I grew up in. I’ve
never been called “too Chinese,” but I’ve definitely been called “not Chinese enough.” I
didn’t really hear that until I came to Shanghai three years ago and began working with
local Chinese people – people who identify as Chinese and grew up within this culture. It
was never said as an insult, more so as a passing statement or a joke. And it didn’t really
bother me because I don’t see myself as Chinese. But I think that if I wanted more of my
Chinese identity, those phrases would really hurt.

entries.title: Blending in
entries.text:
Definitely American/Western sources. Truthfully, I felt very removed from Asian culture. It
felt ‘foreign’ to me and it honestly still does. I very much feel like a foreigner in China. Don’t
get me wrong, Shanghai feels like home, but in the same way it does for any foreigner who
enjoys living here. It doesn’t feel like my ‘homeland.’ My home country is America. Similarly
to what I said in Question #10, growing up I just wanted to fit in with the other Americans
in my city. I wanted to look like everyone else, talk like everyone else, be like everyone else.
My hairstyle is pretty basic, to be fair, but it somehow still looks more Western than
Chinese. Even though after three years of living here most of my clothes have been bought
in Shanghai, I shop at Western stores like H&M and Zara. I’ve wondered before if I would
even be able to pass for a local Chinese girl if I were to put on more ‘local Chinese’ clothing.
I think for the longest time, I wanted to prove to everyone that I was just like everyone else.
So I would shop at Victoria’s Secret and Hollister and do whatever I could to blend in. I still
do that even now.

entries.title: Unknowable truths
entries.text: I paint pictures of different paths for the possibilities of me.To speculate, to hypothesize, to dream, brings me both pain and peace. I suppose that\u2019s all we can do with unknowable truths.

entries.title: Grief and Birth parents
entries.text: How does one grieve someone whom they never knew? Are they even allowed it? Mother, father, are you listening? I await your permission

entries.title: Shanghai Chinese adoptee symposium reflections
entries.text: I often try to intellectualize my adoptee experience, something only learned in last 48 hours is a way of coping with the things that hurt us most. I write, I read, I code, I create, and I research about adoption and about China to try to make sense of it all. I have this fantasy that one day I’ll have written hundreds of peer-reviewed journals, been featured in the most renowned exhibitions, and produced the most ground-breaking research for all my family, friends, colleagues, past lovers, and enemies to see, and that when that day comes, they will finally see me, and I will be happy. I\u2019m beginning to realize that perhaps deep down I chase this fantasy to cope with the things I am too afraid to feel. \n\nBut sometimes, no amount of thinking can mend the pain, suffering, and heartbreak that being an adoptee is. It doesn’t explain why I sometimes pray to every god I know begging for a reshuffling of the cards I’ve been dealt. It doesn’t explain how adoption makes me feel simultaneously confused, grounded, stupid, smart, ugly, beautiful, ashamed, and proud all at once. I thought I knew what would make me happy-what would heal me-but actually, I don’t have the slightest idea. At this year’s symposium, I asked myself to feel all of these things, without reaching into my back pocket of terminologies and APA citations for help. I sobbed, I laughed, I told stories. I allowed myself to have fun, and I allowed myself to grieve. I felt the comfort of reconnecting with old friends and the joy of making new ones. I got angry at the world for tearing us apart and then thanked it for bringing us together. Like 落叶归根 suggests, I let myself fall and flow with the wind. I let myself hit the ground. I let myself wither and seep into the soil. For once, I stop fighting and let gravity take over. I rest.

entries.title: My Adoptive parents
entries.text:
Growing up, the common expectation was that the adoptee ought to be eternally grateful to be in the lives of their adoptive parents. They ought to feel lucky to be a part of their lives. And in return, adoptive parents ought to be, well, good adoptive parents: they ought to see their child as their own, and they ought to support their child in their adoptee journey in any way that they can. Once these boxes have been ticked, criticism towards the adoptive parent and their methods ought to be completely out of line and seen as a sign of “disrespect” or “ungratefulness”. 

This is not to say that I didn’t meet this expectation, I did very much so fit into this box, especially growing up. 

But as I grow older and I begin to have thoughts and experiences that they could never even imagine, suddenly that unconditional support I felt as a kid, is no longer there.

I feel myself drifting farther and farther apart from my parents, and I 
The rose tinted glasses have come off, and I’ve grown to see my parents as not the perfect adoptive parents I once believed they were. But that is okay. We as adoptees need to realize that no matter how much we want to deny and avoid it, no matter how much we tell ourselves and those around us that yes, these Are are real parents and we wouldn’t trade them for the world, that there is always going to be a disconnect, a strain in our relationship that biological children will NEVER experience with their parents. It’s a feeling of unfamiliarity, of betrayal that the people you love so much might not be able to support your identity in the way that you wish. It’s that pit in your stomach that forms when you come home after months or years and feel like you are talking to strangers.


You still feel alone because it’s your own parents, the one two people in your life who you love and care for with all your heart, have betrayed you, by exhisting as white parents and refusing to acknowledge that their whiteness could and will harm their child. With zero ties to you or your heritage, it feels like betrayal when my parents chose to live in absolutely bum fuck no where, to send me to a private school with all white kids, to only be surrounded by their white-collar friends who were all white, who were all doctors, and who all had white, privileged kids.

entries.title: The Adoptee's Burden
entries.text:
It’s the trauma of racial shame that only increases as the years go by
Piling up like a to-do list that never ends

It’s your entire life pre-adoption
stuck to the bottom of your shoe like a wad of pink bubblegum 

it’s the obligation to try to understand a language that might not ever understand you 
the 

it’s the guilt of never wanting anything to do with your birth parents. 
and the soul crushing disappointment of not being able to know them enough 

It’s crippling responsibility of having to constantly educate your own parents on their whiteness  
s
It’s the pressure to have your own kids, to not let your genome die in the Walmart parking lot of American suburbia. 

It’s the need to be overly personal with people, just to see if they can understand, 
As well as the regret of sharing too much 


The adoptee’s burden is to have to constantly educate your own fucking parents on their whiteness.

entries.title: Sibling dynamics
entries.text: I think family is the group of people you grow up with. My grandfather, who I’m really close with, is really into our family history, and when he says things like our family goes back to George Washington or something like that, I do feel included in this family. I also acknowledge that it’s not exactly my blood line, but it never bothered me. I love that my brothers never really made a big deal about it like I wasn’t  their Chinese or adopted sister, I was just their annoying little sister Amy. Friends of theirs who met me for the first time would always seem confused like wait she’s Asian? I wouldn’t say this is a huge challenge, but i’ve definitely been mistaken as my brother’s girlfriend.

entries.title: I identify more with American culture...
entries.text: I identify more with American culture, but I think that is because I am a foreigner living in China. If I was back home in Charlotte, NC, I may feel excluded from the culture at times. Even watching from afar on social media, I see how I identify less and less with my hometown and more with the people around me (who also look more like me). I think being an adoptee has at times definitely made it hard feeling close to Asian or Chinese-American culture because I didn’t grow up in Asian environments. I didn’t have Asian family members, so some of the commonalities many Asians have I feel left out of. Still, I look Chinese and when a stranger sees me at first glance, they don’t  know my upbringing or background, so I am subject to discrimination just like any other Asian looking person, so there is some solidarity in that. I may have different life experiences than other Asians, but there is still a strong sense of Chineseness or Asianness that can’t be stripped away even though I am adopted.

entries.title: My thoughts on 'being in the fog'
entries.text:
There are two main viewpoints on adoption. The first, more commonly understood one, is that adoption is the altruistic act of helping a child in need, giving them a better life than they would have had if they weren’t adopted. This is what the adoption industry wants you to believe. This is what most people in your life want you to believe. This is what so many adoptive parents want you to believe. 
	The second viewpoint, is the one I would hope that by the end of reading this, you can come to terms with, which is that adoption is not an individual act of                                             mc , but a carefully calculated transaction of human capital, part of a larger, global network that is used as a tool of modern day colonialism and white supremacy. This is the perspective that no one wants to talk about. This is the perspective that gets people looking at you like you’re crazy. This is the perspective that is so incredibly hard to digest. 
	Of course, one could say that these two perspectives are the two extremes of a much wider, diverse, range of perspectives out there. It could be said that making sense of one’s own adoption is as much as it is a rocky road as it is a spectrum, with the two extremes being on either end of it. The unfortunate thing is, while I would love for revery adoptee out there to be able to understand how turbulent, traumatic, and inherently problematic adoption is, it’s an opinion that most consider too radical to even consider. Not every adoptee will reach this point ever in their life, and if they do, there’s no telling how long it will take. Moreover, there are so many factors that play into the likelihood and the timeframe of an adoptee’s journey out of The Fog. For example, the town in which one grew up in, how open one’s parents are about adoption, their relationship and proximity to other Chinese people, their knowledge of adoption, are just some of the many factors that play a role in an adoptee’s discovery of their past. Of course, I also strongly believe that it also has to do with the personality of an adoptee, regardless of external factors. All adoptees, just like non-adoptees, are so different from one another, and will have different experiences no matter what. 
	In my experience, I grew up with parents who, for the most part, were incredibly supportive of who I was as an adoptee. They took me to Chinese school, let me learn Chinese, travelled with me to China, etc. Whether they’ve been able to accept the responsibility and take restorative action for the trauma they have caused me—that’s a different story that I discuss in a different chapter. Though all in all, I would say I finally got out of being in the fog when I was a freshman in college, and since then, I’ve been constantly reflecting on, criticizing, researching, and questioning my upbringing, trying to realign my past and present so that I can continue to work through the trauma in my life.

entries.title: hello
entries.text: testing topic modelling

entries.title: hello

entries.title: hellooo
entries.text: testing tpic modelling

entries.title: I'm not like my parents
entries.text: I think people like to play too much into the idea that your adoptive parents are “just like” your real parents, that there isn’t really such a thing as “adoptive” parents - they are just your parents. And while this blanket statement was helpful during my adolescence when I was constantly dealing with people asking me with a condescending glare, “who are your REAL parents?”, now this type of rhetoric seems to do more harm than good. Because as you grow older you begin to be able to formulate and vocalize real, objective opinions about your parents; you gain a valuable perspective on the type of people your parents are, their values and morals. However, being adopted and coming from a relatively healthy childhood complicates this, because even now, though I’m able to critically examine where my parents have “gone wrong” — not only as parents but as ADOPTIVE parents — , I find myself feeling guilty for having such opinions, because I’ve been conditioned my whole life to believe that these are in fact my real parents and I should be eternally grateful for that. And so at almost 21 years old I’m grappling with the reality that my parents and I view the world very differently—socially, politically—and a large part of that has to do with me being adopted, and a large part of me struggling to come to terms with that is the expectations that are set for adoptive parents and their children.

entries.title: What it means to grow up
entries.text: I think we probably have all experienced some form of growing distance fro your parents. It’s an inevitable part of growing up. You mature and realize that some things your parents do just annoy the fuck out of you. And there’s also some things your parents do or might say that you’ve just come to not agree with.

entries.title: What it means to grow up
entries.text: I think we probably have all experienced some form of growing distance fro your parents. It’s an inevitable part of growing up. You mature and realize that some things your parents do just annoy the fuck out of you. And there’s also some things your parents do or might say that you’ve just come to not agree with.

entries.title: What it means to grow up
entries.text: I think we probably have all experienced some form of growing distance fro your parents. It’s an inevitable part of growing up. You mature and realize that some things your parents do just annoy the fuck out of you. And there’s also some things your parents do or might say that you’ve just come to not agree with.

entries.title: Not being enough
entries.text:
To be honest I probably have at one point, but when I was younger like in middle
and high school, I think I brushed a lot of these things off and looking back there
were probably loads of microaggressions that I didn’t even realize were
microaggressions at the time (not to sound too much like a victim lol). I think
growing up I don’t remember a specific instance where someone said this, but I
feel like the general vibe was like oh Amy you’re not like the other Asians, you’re
more like us, which is like oh cool I am accepted, but on the other hand awful
because it’s like a whole part of my identity is devalued. It’s like you are
rewarded for your whiteness.

entries.text:

and high school, I think I brushed a lot of these things off and looking back there
were probably loads of microaggressions that I didn’t even realize were
microaggressions at the time (not to sound too much like a victim lol). I think
